[[Mentioned in Despatches]] (5){{LondonGazette| issue=32940| date=30 May 1924| startpage=4308| accessdate=12 September 2013}}{{London Gazette| issue=34282| date=8 May 1936| startpage=2979| accessdate=14 February 2012}}{{London Gazette| issue=37368| date=27 November 1945| supp=y| startpage=5791| endpage=5830| accessdate=14 February 2012}}{{London Gazette| issue=38581| date=8 April 1949| startpage=1759| supp=y| accessdate=14 February 2012}} |laterwork= Colonel of the 3rd Queen Alexandra's Own Gurkha Rifles (1946){{London Gazette| issue=38598| date=29 April 1949| startpage=2111| supp=| accessdate=14 February 2012}} }} [[Major-general (United Kingdom)|Major General]] '''Sir Charles Hamilton Boucher''' {{postnominals|country=GBR|size=100%|sep=,|KBE|CB|DSO}} & [[Medal bar|Bar]] (26 October 1898 – 14 November 1951) was an [[Officer (armed forces)|officer]] in the [[British Indian Army]] during the [[World War I|First]] and [[World War II|Second World Wars]]. ==Early life and career== Boucher was born on 26 October 1898, the son of Lieutenant Colonel C. H. Boucher. He was educated at Wellington College from 1912 to 1915,Wellington College Register p306 after which he attended Wellington Cadet College in India.London Gazette 6 February 1917 page 1281 - see header on section announcing his commission Boucher was [[Commissioned officer|commissioned]] into the Unattached List for the Indian Army on 14 November 1916 and was appointed to the Indian Army on 1 December, attached to [[2nd King Edward VII's Own Gurkha Rifles (The Sirmoor Rifles)]]{{London Gazette| issue=30017| startpage=3512 |date=13 April 1917 }} although he was later to transfer to the [[3 Gorkha Rifles|3rd Queen Alexandra's Own Gurkha Rifles]] in 1919. He was promoted to [[lieutenant]] on 14 November 1917{{London Gazette| issue=30655| startpage=5071| date=26 April 1918}} and saw service against the Marris in India from 1 March to 8 April 1918, then saw service in Palestine in October 1918.Indian Army Supplement 1941 After the war he returned to India and saw action on the North West Frontier in Waziristan during the period 1919–21 and 1921–24. He was [[Mentioned in Despatches]]. He was promoted captain on 14 November 1920. Indian Army List April 1923 Boucher attended the Staff College, Camberley from 1931 to 1932.[http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/viewArticle.arc?articleId=ARCHIVE-The_Times-1951-11-19-08-020&pageId=ARCHIVE-The_Times-1951-11-19-08 Obituary, The Times 19 November 1951] In April 1933 he was appointed a General Staff Officer Grade III.{{London Gazette| issue=33952| date=23 June 1933| startpage=4206| accessdate=14 February 2012}} In November 1934 he relinquished the staff post and was promoted to major{{London Gazette| issue=34116| date=21 December 1934| startpage=8298 | accessdate=14 February 2012}} to take up a field appointment as a brigade major.{{London Gazette| issue=34241| date=10 January 1936| startpage=237| accessdate=14 February 2012}} In 1936 for "distinguished services rendered in the field in connection with the Mohmand Operations, North West Frontier of India, during the period 15th/16th August to 15th/16th October 1935" he was awarded the [[Distinguished Service Order]] (DSO).{{London Gazette| issue=34282| startpage=2978| date=8 May 1936}} He was appointed an instructor at the [[Command and Staff College|Staff College, Quetta]] from 21 January 1938 to 21 September 1940 with the local rank of lieutenant colonel.{{London Gazette| issue=34496| date=25 March 1938| startpage=2011| accessdate=14 February 2012}}[http://www.generals.dk/general/Boucher/Sir_Charles_Hamilton/Great_Britain.html Generals.dk] ==Second World War== Boucher served throughout the [[Second World War]], initially as a [[General Staff Officer]] Grade 1, Home Forces from 26 October 1940 to 18 May 1941 before being made a [[brigadier]] on the [[General Staff]] of [[Paiforce]] in [[Iraq]] from 19 May 1941 to 29 March 1942.Half Yearly Army List January 1946 In April 1942 he was appointed to command the [[10th Indian Infantry Brigade]] in [[North Africa]]. While commanding the brigade he was captured on 6 June 1942 during the fighting in the [[Battle of Gazala|Knightsbridge Cauldron]] when his [[headquarters]] were overrun. He was held as a [[prisoner of war]] in Italy until the [[Armistice with Italy]] in September 1943, when he made his way back to the [[Allies of World War II|Allied]] lines in southern Italy. During his confinement his substantive rank was advanced from major to lieutenant colonel (while his temporary rank remained as brigadier){{London Gazette| issue=35974| date=9 April 1943 | startpage=1645| accessdate=14 February 2012}} and he was also made a [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] (CBE) in 1943 "in recognition of gallant and distinguished services in Iraq, Syria and Persia during the period April 1941 to February 1942".{{London Gazette| issue=35862| date=12 January 1943| startpage=319| supp=y| accessdate=12 September 2013}} On 8 February 1944 Boucher assumed command of the [[17th Indian Infantry Brigade]], leading the unit through the final [[Battle of Monte Cassino]], the advance north of Rome and the fighting on the [[Gothic Line]]. For his service in Italy he was awarded a [[medal bar|Bar]] to his DSO and made a [[Companion of the Order of the Bath]] in 1945. He was also mentioned in despatches. On 19 January 1945, with the rank of acting major general,{{London Gazette| issue=37263| date=14 September 1945| startpage=4563| supp=y| accessdate=14 February 2012}} Boucher took command of the [[4th Infantry Division (India)|Indian 4th Infantry Division]], which had been sent to Greece in November 1944 to help stabilise the country after the [[Axis powers|Axis]] withdrawal. For his "gallant and distinguished services in the field" he was mentioned in despatches in 1946.{{London Gazette| issue=37616| date=18 June 1946| startpage=3564| accessdate=14 February 2012}} Leaving Greece after a year he trained as a parachutist in Britain in order to take command of Indian 2nd Airborne Division in Karachi early in 1946. His temporary major general's rank was made permanent in 1947,{{London Gazette| issue=38051| date=19 August 1947| supp=y| startpage=3933| accessdate=14 February 2012}} and in 1948 he became General Officer Commanding [[Malaya Command|Malaya District]] as well as Major General Commanding the [[Brigade of Gurkhas]] in Malaya. For his service in Malaya he was knighted as a [[Knight Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] in 1949, and was mentioned in despatches. He retired in March 1951{{London Gazette| issue=39201| date=13 April 1951| supp=| startpage=2069| accessdate=14 February 2012}} through ill health and died on 14 November that year. ==Family== He married Edith Margaret, daughter of M. F. Ramsay, J.P. of Lee Priory, Littlebourne, Kent in 1926. He had one son and one daughter.Kelly's Handbook to the Titled, Landed and Official Classes 1944 ==References== *{{Cite book | author=Anon| title=One More River: The Story of The Eighth Indian Division| publisher=H.W.
